title: Arduino Push Button: Digital Input and Control
description: This unit introduces students to reading digital input from push buttons with Arduino. Students will learn how to connect a push button to an Arduino, read its state using digitalRead(), and use that input to control outputs like LEDs. Emphasis is placed on understanding pull-up and pull-down resistors, the difference between input and output pins, and how to use conditional statements to respond to button presses.
understandings: Push buttons are digital input devices that provide HIGH or LOW signals when pressed or released.
Digital input pins must be configured using pinMode() with INPUT mode to read button states.
The digitalRead() function reads the state of a digital input pin, returning either HIGH or LOW.
Pull-up or pull-down resistors are necessary to ensure a button has a defined state when not pressed, preventing floating values.
Conditional statements (if/else) allow programs to respond differently based on button state.
Buttons can be used to control outputs, toggle states, or trigger actions in microcontroller programs.
essentialQuestions: How does a push button work as a digital input device, and what signals does it provide when pressed or released?
Why must input pins be configured differently than output pins, and how does pinMode() affect pin behavior?
What is the purpose of pull-up or pull-down resistors in a button circuit, and what happens if they are omitted?
How does digitalRead() differ from digitalWrite(), and when would you use each function?
How can you use conditional statements to make your program respond to button presses in different ways?
What are some practical applications where reading button input and controlling outputs would be useful in a real-world project?

vocabDefinitions.Push Button: A simple switch that completes or breaks an electrical circuit when pressed, providing a digital HIGH or LOW signal.
vocabDefinitions.Digital Input: A pin configured to read digital signals (HIGH or LOW) from sensors, buttons, or other input devices.
vocabDefinitions.digitalRead(): An Arduino function that reads the state of a digital input pin, returning HIGH (1) or LOW (0) based on the voltage level.
vocabDefinitions.Pull-Up Resistor: A resistor connected between a pin and VCC (5V) that keeps the pin HIGH when the button is not pressed, preventing floating values.
vocabDefinitions.Pull-Down Resistor: A resistor connected between a pin and GND (ground) that keeps the pin LOW when the button is not pressed, preventing floating values.
vocabDefinitions.Button State: The current condition of a button, either pressed (HIGH or LOW depending on wiring) or not pressed (opposite state).
vocabDefinitions.HIGH: A digital signal representing a voltage near 5V (or 3.3V on 3.3V boards), typically interpreted as 'on' or 'true'.
vocabDefinitions.LOW: A digital signal representing a voltage near 0V (ground), typically interpreted as 'off' or 'false'.
vocabDefinitions.Floating Pin: An input pin that is not connected to a defined voltage level, which can cause unpredictable readings and should be avoided.
vocabDefinitions.Input Pin: A pin on the Arduino configured using pinMode(pin, INPUT) to read signals from sensors, buttons, or other input devices.
